Award.AwardTitle: Assessing tropical Pacific climate variability since the Early Pliocene warm period
Award.AbstractNarration:
Paleoceanographic studies have shown that early Pliocene warm period (~3.0 to 4.5 million years ago) was characterized by a permanent El Niño-like mean state. However, it is unclear how high frequency climate variability (e.g., the El Niño Southern Oscillation, or ENSO) was different (if at all), and more generally, how ENSO was impacted by changes in the mean state of the climate system. Questions remain about potential biases in the data, and little is known about high frequency tropical Pacific climate variability during the early Pliocene warm period.

This accomplishment-based renewal aims to address these outstanding issues by building on over fifteen years of prior research by the lead investigator, a professor at the University of California at Santa Cruz. Her pioneering work has established much of what is known about the Pliocene, the most recent period in Earth's history when when the average global temperature was higher than today for a sustained period of time. This two part study will include 1) synthesis and review of existing records of early Pliocene variability on different time scales, and 2) generation of new paired Mg/Ca-d18O analyses on single foraminifer shells in order to evaluate within-sample variability thought to be related to high frequency ENSO variability.

The principal investigator has trained a generation of students in the techniques and questions framing this research. A graduate student will also be involved in this research and synthesis. A significant part of the proposed work will be a workshop on tropical Pacific climate variability during times of global warmth, especially significant because the Pliocene warm period is thought to be a potential analog for future climate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The tropical Pacific is a major source of heat and moisture to the atmosphere, and therefore changes in condition in the tropical Pacific are important drivers of global climate change. Furthermore, the tropical Pacific is the region responsible for the generation of El Niño events, which have far-field impacts across the world’s oceans and continents.  Global climate changes over the last five million years include a transition from the globally warm early Pliocene period to the Pleistocene ice ages; studying these long-term global changes, and their relationship to the amplitude of El Niño events, provides an opportunity to understand whether extreme El Niño events can be predicted in the face of global warming. To this end, this project explored changes in the mean state of the tropical Pacific over the last 5 million years, including the generation of Mg/Ca data, measured on planktonic foraminifera, to resolve long-term trends and orbital scale cycles in sea surface and subsurface temperature. In addition, changes in the amplitude of El Niño events were interpreted from Mg/Ca measurements of groups of single foraminifera tests from climatically important time periods.

We found that the mean state of the thermocline in the west Pacific has cooled/shoaled since the Pliocene (Ford et al., 2015), similar to what was previously discovered in the east Pacific, that the mean state (zonal gradient and development of the cold tongue in the east equatorial Pacific) intensified through the Pliocene and Pleistocene (Dyez and Ravelo, 2014). We reaffirmed that there was a reduced, but not absent, west-east difference across the equatorial Pacific, that increased as global climate cooled and the Ice Ages began (Ravelo et al., 2014). The changes in mean state can be accounted for by a combination of a response to radiative forcing caused by changed in greenhouse gas concentrations, ocean dynamical responses to changes in extratropical solar radiation and climate (glaciation) (Dyez and Ravelo, 2013; Dyez et al., 2016) and since the Pliocene, possibly to changes in upper ocean mixing and cloud albedo (Fedorov et al., 2013). These changes in mean state should have theoretically impacted the strength of the feedbacks that determine the amplitude of El Niño events, and our reconstructions do show that this occurred. Our reconstructions of El Niño events show that the Late Holocene/recent samples in the west, central, and east Pacific provide an accurate reconstruction of modern ENSO and seasonal variability (Ford et al., 2015; White et al., in review), that ENSO was reduced in the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) due to reduced thermocline and upwelling feedback strength because the thermocline was relatively deep (Ford et al., 2015), and that ENSO was reduced during the Pliocene warm period also due to reduced thermocline and upwelling feedback strength (White and Ravelo, in prep). The implications are that deepening or warming of the thermocline, if it occurs in the future, could be an important driver of reduced El Niño amplitude.

This project provide partial funding for several undergraduate and graduate students; it partially supported Kelsey Dyez and Heather Ford as they finished their dissertations, and was the main source of extramural funding in support of Sarah White who is in the doctoral program at UCSC. It provided partial support for work that was included in seven peer-reviewed publications and four conference presentations.
